Graphical abstract Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) are emerging as clean and renewable energy sources for global-scale sustainable energy solutions. However, several limitations of the current standard catalyst (platinum supported carbon black: Pt/C) prevent their commercialization. As an effective co-catalyst, Au@CeO2 core-shell structures are greatly advantageous for getting over the remaining hurdles of Pt/C in DMFCs. Herein, we report an efficient approach for the fabrication of electrocatalyst for DMFCs consisting of three components (Pt/C, Au@CeO2 and Pt catalysts) loaded on carbon cloth using spray and electrophoresis deposition methods. The obtained Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst proved to have high electrochemical surface area (ECSA-77.8 m2/gPt) and high methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) activity (1267 mA/mgPt), which were 1.7 and 2.3 times greater than those of Pt/C only (45.6 m2/gPt and 560 mA/mgPt). In addition, the presence of Au@CeO2 nanoparticles can further enhance the stability of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst toward the MOR activity. The improved MOR performance of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst could be mainly attributed to the production of abundant OHads promoters, reduction of charge transfer resistance and enhancement of Pt catalytic efficient utilization. It helps to wholly oxidize COads intermediate as dominant poisoning species on Pt catalyst, which are often generated during the MOR operation in acidic condition. Keywords DMFCs MOR Platinum Au@CeO2 core-shell nanoparticles Electrophoresis deposition 1 Introduction Fuel cells, which can directly convert chemical energy into electrical energy, are emerging as clean and renewable energy sources for global-scale sustainable energy solutions [1,2]. Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs), in particular, have attracted much attention due to their distinctive advantages. They may be substituted for conventional batteries in portable electronic devices because of their high-energy conversion efficiency and low environmental effect [3]. Further, DMFCs have various advantages compared to hydrogen fuel cells, such as the fact that methanol is a stable liquid, making it convenient to handle, store and transport; methanol can produce higher energy density than hydrogen; methanol can be directly injected into cell stacks without fuel reforming or sulfur removal; DMFCs can work at lower temperatures than hydrogen; and finally, methanol is an inexpensive liquid that is biologically renewable [4,5]. Furthermore, methanol, as the simplest alcohol with no carbon-carbon (C-C) bond, can be wholly oxidized to carbon dioxide (CO2) releasing six electrons, versus only the two electrons produced from hydrogen oxidation [6,7]. Current standard catalysts for DMFCs include platinum nanoparticles (Pt NPs) (2–5 nm particle size)-supported carbon materials with large surface areas (Pt/C) [8]. They show high mass-specific surface areas (30–90) m2/gPt [9], leading to both high specific activity (approximately 200 μA/cm2 Pt) and high mass activity (0.1–0.3 A/mgPt at 0.9 V) [1]. Additionally, the Pt/C composite catalyst is of sufficient porosity to accelerate the transport of electrons and reactants during the electrocatalytic operation [10,11]. However, there are several hurdles of Pt/C which limit the commercialization and industrialization of DMFCs. First, the pure Pt catalyst may not satisfy the ever-increasing demands of applications at low cost because of its resource scarcity and high cost [12]. Secondly, the weak van der Waals interactions between Pt and carbon lead to easy aggregation as well as detachment from the corrosion of support materials [13,14]. Furthermore, the activity of the Pt catalyst supported on carbon can be pronely poisoned by the carbon intermediates, for instance, COads, which are often produced during the methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) [15,16]; hence, it is still a main challenge so far. Therefore, exploring the efficient catalysts which can improve the activity and utilization of Pt/C while minimizing usage amount is necessary and meaningful. In order to reduce the COads poisoning effects in the MOR, it is essential to develop effective catalysts, which can provide more oxygenated species, for instance, hydroxyl species (OHads) are suitable candidates to oxidize COads intermediates [17]. In this respect, the first trial is to use metallic Pt-M alloy catalysts (M: Ru, Rh, Ni, Co, Pd, Fe, Cu, etc) with various morphologies [18,19]. Oxophilic metals could form adsorbed OHads species from the dissociation of adsorbed water, then promote the oxidation of adsorbed COads intermediates [20]. In this case, the combination between Ru and Pt is the best catalyst for COads tolerance [19]. However, Ru dissolution can occur to degrade the MOR performance [21] and it is also costly. Hence, the COads poisoning issue is still a main obstacle for the catalysts in DMFCs. Alternatively, metal oxides could be considered to be efficient catalysts to improve the activity of Pt/C because of the Pt-oxides strong interactions and could concurrently reduce the amount of Pt usage [22,23]. There are advantages to metal oxides being incorporated with Pt/C catalysts, such as being low cost and easily-synthesized materials, being stable materials in acidic and alkaline media [24]. Furthermore, the oxides are also capable of generating more OHads species from the dissolution of water molecules, which then enhance the tolerance of COads poisoning on the surface of catalysts [25–27]. Finally, it can modulate to the electronic structure and change in the d-band center of the Pt catalyst by the charge transfer [27–29] to weaken the adsorptive strength of COads poisoning species. Among various metal oxides, ceria (CeO2) is of particular interest as a promising co-catalyst for improving the activity and stability of the Pt/C catalyst in DMFCs [24–27,30–34]. The fluorite structure of CeO2 makes its cations can be variable oxidation states between Ce3+ and Ce4+, enabling the storage and release of oxygen at low temperature [21], thus it could serve as an oxygen buffer [34]. Because of its high oxygen carrying ability, CeO2 could also improve the removal of adsorbed COads intermediates on the Pt catalyst by providing sufficient oxygenic species at low potentials [21,28]. Further, it is stable catalytic material for both anodic and cathodic reactions [24,35,36]. Finally, the large surface area of CeO2 is favorable for enhancing the uniform dispersion of Pt over its surface and creating strong metal-oxide electronic interactions to prevent the sintering of Pt catalysts during the operating conditions [37]. Unfortunately, CeO2 demonstrates low electron conductivity [38,39] and low oxygen vacancy content [40]; therefore, despite the activity of the CeO2/Pt/C catalysts being improved as compared to Pt/C catalysts, it was still inferior to the standard Pt-Ru/C in DMFCs. One of the potential approaches to further improving the catalytic property of CeO2 is the combination with noble metals. Among noble metals, gold (Au) can be known as the best candidate so far [41–43]. In particular, Au@CeO2 core-shell structures prove better catalytic activity as compared to the individual of Au NPs and CeO2 due to its unique properties. The core-shell structures have high activity and stability [44]. Due to a heterogeneous system, the active sites of the core can be strongly protected by the shell [45] and the interfaces between core and shell become more active sites [46]. The Au@CeO2 core-shell can cause in improving the charge transfer by the redox reactions including the oxidation of Au0 to Au+ and the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ [47] thus increasing the amount of oxygen vacancy. Furthermore, the ceria shell may have rich porosity to allow the reactants to easily contact to the core-shell interfaces. Finally, the core-shell structures provide high surface area, which in turn help the facile deposition of further catalyst components, for example, Pt. These advantages are of great significance to improve the catalytic activity of the Pt/C catalyst for the removal of COads poisoning intermediates in the MOR activity. In this study, we, for the first time, couple Au@CeO2 core-shell structures with Pt/C composites to overcome the remaining challenges of the catalysts using in DMFCs. In which, the catalyst layers (Pt/C, Au@CeO2 and Pt catalysts) are stacked in order on the surface of the microporous layer (MPL) of carbon cloth to form Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst. The main aim of the present work is to maximize the efficient Pt utilization for MOR activity. In addition, the Pt/C, Pt/C-Pt and Pt/C-CeO2-Pt electrocatalysts with almost the same Pt loading are also prepared for comparison. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Fabrication of Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst Fig. 1 clearly describes the schematic sequence for the preparation of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst via three steps. First, carbon cloth (2 cm × 4 cm) was dried at 60 °C for 1 h in the oven in order to remove humidity. Next, 0.2 mL of as-prepared Pt/C catalytic slurry (see Supplementary Material) was uniformly sprayed onto the MPL surface of carbon cloth substrate (W1S1005, Ce-Tech Co.) to form the first catalytic layer and dried at 60 °C for 1 h. Then, the obtained electrode was slowly sprayed with 0.2 mL of as-prepared Au@CeO2 catalytic slurry (see Supplementary Material) to form second catalytic layer and dried at 60 °C for 1 h. Finally, an area (1 cm × 1 cm) of the obtained electrode as working electrode was deposited with the synthesized Pt NPs (see Supplementary Material) by the electrophoresis deposition (EPD) method to form the third catalytic layer with the EPD time of 2 min. The electrocatalyst was dried again at 60 °C overnight in an oven before use. In order to perform the EPD process, a three-electrode electrochemical setup was used (Gamry instruments, Reference 3000 Potentiostat/Galvanostat/ZRA). The carbon cloth loaded with Pt/C and Au@CeO2 serving as a working electrode was immersed into an EPD bath containing 500 mL of Pt colloidal solution. A platinum plate and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) were used as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively. Necessarily, the pH value of Pt colloidal solution was reduced to 2 by using sulfuric acid prior to the experiments, which could help easily move the Pt catalyst nanoparticles towards the working electrode. Additionally, pulse current density, cycle time (tcycle = ton + toff), duty cycle {θ = ton/(ton + toff)} and EPD bath temperature were constantly kept at 30 mA/cm2, 1 s, 25% and 25 °C, respectively. The Pt/C, Pt/C-Pt and Pt/C-CeO2-Pt electrocatalysts were also prepared for the purposes of comparison (see Supplementary Material). Furthermore, the photographs of as-prepared catalytic slurries and electrocatalysts are also shown in Figs. S1 and S2. The working area of each electrode is constantly kept at 1 cm2 for the CV testing. Detailed experimental conditions of all of as-fabricated electrocatalysts were also summarized in Table S1. 2.2 Physical characterizations The Pt loadings onto all of the as-fabricated electrocatalysts were measured by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometry (ICPS-7500, Shimadzu) after being treated with aqua regia at 100 °C for 10 h and were carefully filtered so as to remove solid components. The morphologies of Pt/C, Au@CeO2 and Pt NPs were analyzed by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL, JEM-2010) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. For HRTEM analysis, the samples were dropped onto a carbon-coated copper grid, then dried at 100 °C overnight. The UV–vis. transmission spectroscopy (Agilent/HP 8453 UV–vis. Spectrophotometer) was recorded at room temperature in the range of 400–700 nm using water as a blank reference sample. The crystal structure of Au@CeO2 NPs was also confirmed by X-ray diffractometry (XRD, D/Max 2005, Rigaku) using CuKα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Multilab 2000) was carried out using monochromated Al Kα X-ray photon (hν = 1486.6 eV) sources to the surface chemical states of the elements existing in Au@CeO2. The binding energies of the adventitious carbon (C 1s) peak located at around 285 eV were used for calibration to other peaks. The surface, cross-sectional images and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) of the working electrocatalysts were all examined by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, S-4800, Hitachi). 2.3 Electrochemical measurements Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was methodically performed on a potentiostat (Gamry instruments, Reference 3000 potentiostat/Galvanostat/ZRA) with the as-prepared electrocatalyst (1 cm × 1 cm) serving as the working electrode. The counter and reference electrodes were graphite rod (diameter 5 mm) and SCE, respectively. The CV testing setup is provided in Fig. S3. The hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) was conducted into a 500 mL beaker containing freshly prepared 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte at a sweep rate of 50 mV/s at 25 °C for electrochemical surface area (ECSA) evaluation. The methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) was obtained in freshly prepared 0.5 M H2SO4 + 1 M CH3OH electrolyte at a sweep rate of 50 mV/s at 25 °C. The stable current-potential performance of the CV curves could be attained after 50 cycle scans. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out in freshly prepared 0.5 M H2SO4 + 1 M CH3OH electrolyte at 25 °C from 100 kHz to 0.05 Hz. Notably, during the electrochemical tests, the electrolytes were saturated with pure N2 by purging to prevent attacks from the oxygen. The CO stripping voltammetry was performed in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte at 25 °C. First, the electrolyte was purged with pure N2 gas for 30 min. Then, the pure CO gas was bubbled into the electrolyte for 20 min at the potential of 0.05 V (vs SCE) for adsorption on the surfaces of catalysts. Lastly, the dissolved CO gas was removed by purging pure N2 for 20 min. The CO stripping voltammetry was recorded at the sweep rate of 50 mV/s. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 2 a shows the HRTEM imagery of the as-synthesized Au cores, which is clearly composed of spherical particles. The particle size distribution histogram of the as-synthesized Au NPs is also presented in Fig. 2b, in which, the average size is observed to be around 15 nm. The uniformity of the as-calcined Au@CeO2 core-shell NPs is clearly confirmed by the HRTEM observation (Fig. 2c). Its shapes and sizes have not changed much as compared to prior to calcination (Fig. S4a). It notes that each particle contains only single core and particles with multiple cores or those without cores have been not observed. The composition of a single Au@CeO2 nanoparticle is investigated by the HRTEM-EDS elemental mapping as shown in Fig. 2d. Thereby, the coexistence of Au (pink), Ce (yellow) and O (green) is detected as shown in Fig. 2(e–g). The corresponding overlay of these elements is provided in Fig. S4b. On the other hand, the distribution of Au, Ce and O elements is further confirmed by the HRTEM-EDS line-scanning profile, as illustrated in Fig. 2h, in which, Au is clearly located in the center of nanoparticle with the size of 15 nm (pink curve). Ce and O elements are detected in the shell (yellow and green curves) with the thickness of 15 nm. Furthermore, the lattice fringes of 0.312 and 0.235 nm can be possibly suited with the (1 1 1) plane of CeO2 shell and (1 1 1) plane of Au core of the Au@CeO2 core-shell NPs (Fig. 2i). The SAED pattern of a single Au@CeO2 nanoparticle shows that the CeO2 shells are polycrystalline in nature (Fig. S4c). The uniform morphology of the as-calcined Au@CeO2 NPs is also proven by FESEM observation (Fig. 2j), where the mean size of Au@CeO2 NPs is also found to be around 45 nm, which is well matched with the HRTEM analysis above. The HRTEM and FESEM analyses clearly reveal that the shell is composed of tiny CeO2 nanocrystals with sizes in the range of 3 to 5 nm; this results in the large microporous surface of the Au@CeO2 core-shell like the Hala’s surface structures, as illustrated in Fig. S5a. This is greatly advantageous for the strong dispersion of Pt catalyst and for preventing the sintering of Pt NPs. Fig. S5b shows the FESEM-EDS spectrum, which again confirms the coexistence of Au, Ce and O in the as-calcined Au@CeO2 core-shell structures. On the other hand, the HRTEM and FESEM analysis of pure CeO2 NPs, with the same size to Au@CeO2 NPs, are also provided in Fig. S6. In addition, the UV–vis. spectrum of Au colloidal suspension is measured (Fig. 3 a). A surface plasmon absorption peak is centered at 520 nm in the pink curve and this belongs to the 15 nm sized Au NPs. However, after the coating of CeO2 shell, Au absorption peak is red-shifted to 542 nm in red curve (Fig. 3a). This red shift as large as 22 nm, can be due to not only the higher refractive index of CeO2 (2.18) as compared to water (1.33) [48] but also the decrease of free electron density on the Au surface by the electron transfer from the Au core to the CeO2 shell after the shell formation [49], thus, leading to the increase of Ce3+ amount in CeO2 [50] and the great improvement of the catalytic properties of the Au@CeO2 core-shell NPs. In addition, the crystalline structures of the synthesized Au, pure CeO2 and Au@CeO2 materials were analyzed by XRD (Fig. 3b). In the case of Au@CeO2 core-shell NPs, the diffraction peaks of the Au core marked with (†) at 2θ values of 38.3, 44.5 and 64.8 correspond to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0) and (2 2 0) crystalline planes, respectively and it is well indexed to face-centered cubic gold (JCPDS No. 04-0784). Other peaks marked with (*) are observed at 28.5, 33.2, 47.7, 56.4, 59.3, 69.7, 77.0 and 79.4°, which belong to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (2 2 2), (4 0 0), (3 3 1) and (4 2 0) crystalline planes of cubic fluorite structure of the CeO2 shell (JCPDS No. 04-0593). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is performed in order to determine the surface chemical states of the elements existing in the Au@CeO2 core-shell catalyst. Fig. 3c provides the survey spectrum of the XPS of the as-calcined Au@CeO2 NPs, which further confirm the coexistence of Au, Ce and O without impurities. The XPS spectrum of the Au 4f core level is given in Fig. 3d and it can clearly be seen that both metallic and ionic Au species are present in the core-shell structures. The binding energies centered at 83.50 and 87.26 eV belong to Au0, while the binding energies centered at 84.66 and 88.75 eV are assigned to Au+ ions and the Au+/Au0 ratio is 0.25. The formation of Au+ ions can be due to the interaction between the Au core and the CeO2 shell, which results in the transfer of electrons from core to shell and producing Ce3+ ions by reduction of Ce4+ ions [51,52]. Therefore, the free electron density on the surface of Au in core-shell structures was reduced as compared to free Au colloid. It is agreeable with the change of Au absorption peak in UV–vis. spectra mentioned above (Fig. 3a). The existence of Au+ species can improve the catalyst property of the core-shell structures since its electron configuration is similar to the Pt element [53]. In addition, the Ce 3d XPS spectrum of the Au@CeO2 catalyst is clearly divided into eight peaks as shown in Fig. 3e. The peaks marked in pink are characteristic of Ce4+ ions and the peaks marked in green correspond to Ce3+ ions, indicating the existence of a mixture of Ce4+/Ce3+ oxidation state in the core-shell structures. The relative amount of Ce3+ ions in Au@CeO2 can be estimated by the integration of Ce3+ peaks area with regard to the total area of the Ce 3d spectrum. For comparison, the XPS spectra of pure CeO2 is also provided in Fig. S7 and the comparison results are shown in Table S2. It is clear that the concentration of Ce3+ ions in the Au@CeO2 core-shell (31.69%) is higher than that of pure CeO2 (22.38%), which is due to the formation of the Au@CeO2 nanostructures. Indeed, the coating of the CeO2 shell can lead to the transfer of electrons from the metal to the oxide surface. As an electron scavenger, Ce4+ can easily trap the electrons transferred from the metal to form Ce3+ions [51], which play an important role for CO oxidation in this study. In order to confirm the status of oxygen species in Au@CeO2 NPs, the XPS spectrum of O 1s is measured (Fig. 3f). In which, the curve is fitted into three peaks including the peak centered at 529.23 eV, which is assigned to the lattice oxygen (OL: O2− around Ce4+), the peak centered at 530.94 eV, which is attributable to the oxygen vacancy (OV) and the peak centered at 532.00 eV, which is characteristic of the chemisorbed oxygen species (OC: OH− radicals, adsorbed oxygen, or carbonyl groups) [54]. The relative percentage of each oxygen species in Au@CeO2 is shown in Table S2. Thereby, the relative contents of OV (29.59%) and OC (17.58%) in Au@CeO2 are much higher than those of pure CeO2 (16.16 and 12.97%). The formation of the Au@CeO2 core-shell structures not only leads to the increase of OV species but also makes it more advantageous for generating many oxygen species, which are important for promoting the removal of CO species. Fig. 4 a shows the HRTEM imagery of the as-synthesized Pt NPs, in which the Pt catalysts consist of uniformly spherical particles that are well separated with each other without any agglomeration. Fig. 4b is the representative HRTEM imagery of single Pt catalyst NPs with the lattice fringe of 0.226 nm, which is consistent with the distance of Pt (1 1 1) crystal plane. The mean size of the as-synthesized Pt NPs is about 1.86 nm (as shown in Fig. 4c). Furthermore, Fig. 4d provides the HRTEM imagery of the Pt/C catalyst composite and it notes that the uniform Pt particles are well decorated on the carbon black support. The lattice fringe of 0.226 nm is agreeable with the (1 1 1) crystal plane of Pt catalyst supported on carbon black (Fig. 4e). Fig. 4f also shows the particle size distribution of Pt catalyst in Pt/C composites with the average diameter of 4.06 nm. The diameter of carbon supports is also found in the range of (40 to 70) nm (Fig. 4d). Based on the HRTEM analysis, Pt catalyst NPs are of a very narrow size distribution in both cases (synthesized Pt colloidal and Pt/C composite catalysts), which can support more active sites for enhancing the catalytic reaction performances of as-fabricated working electrodes. The surface of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst is first observed by the FESEM analysis. Prior to the experiment, the carbon cloth contained a smooth surface of the MPL, which consisted of uniformly spherical carbon particles with the average size of 50 nm (Fig. 5 a). After spraying, the Pt/C composite catalyst was deposited on the surface of MPL (Fig. 5b), while the size of the Pt catalyst supported on carbon was not much changed. Then, Au@CeO2 NPs were successfully decorated on the surface of the sprayed Pt/C layer as shown by red arrows (Fig. 5c). Fig. 5d presents the FESEM surface imagery of electrocatalyst after the EPD of the synthesized Pt catalyst NPs. It is clear that the synthesized Pt catalyst is well dispersed on the surface of sprayed Au@CeO2 layer. Thus, the obtained Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrode can provide more catalytic active sites for the electrochemical reactions. For comparison, the FESEM surface imageries of the Pt/C, Pt/C-Pt and Pt/C-CeO2-Pt electrocatalysts are also observed as provided in Fig. S8. In these, the surface of the Au@CeO2/Pt/C working electrode has uniform dispersion of the Pt catalyst among all of the as-prepared electrodes. In addition, the microstructures of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt working electrocatalyst were specifically investigated by the FESEM cross-sectional analysis. An overview of the FESEM cross-sectional imagery for the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst is clearly represented in Fig. 5e, where the surface of electrode includes two main layers, the MPL and the catalyst. The thickness of MPL is around 30 µm, as highlighted by the white arrow, while the thickness of the catalyst layer is around 3 µm, which consists of Pt/C, Au@CeO2 and Pt layers, as illustrated by the green box in the inset of Fig. 5e. The presences of C, Pt, Au, Ce and O in the catalyst layer are detected by the FESEM-EDS cross-sectional elemental mapping and are highlighted by red, yellow, blue, green and pink in Fig. 5(f–j) and the corresponding overlay is shown in Fig. S9, respectively. The main components, C and Pt, show stronger mapping colors than those of Ce and O. In particular, Au exhibits a strong blue color, even in small amounts, owing to the overlapping of the Pt signal, because the EDS spectra of Au and Pt are nearly similar (Fig. 5k). On the other hand, the coexistence of these elements onto the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt working catalytic electrode was evidently confirmed by the FESEM-EDS composition spectrum as well (Fig. 5k). In order to study the electrocatalytic properties of the Pt/C, Pt/C-Pt, Pt/C-CeO2-Pt and Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalysts, the CV was firstly performed in N2-saturated solution of 0.5 M H2SO4 and the obtained results are shown in Fig. 6 a. It is noticeable that the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst demonstrates far better HOR performance with larger hydrogen desorption/adsorption peak from −0.2 to +0.1 V (vs SCE) among all of the as-prepared ones. By integrating the hydrogen desorption peak area, the Pt active area was calculated after the double layer correction by the following equation [55]; P t a c t i v e a r e a = Q H 0.21 where QH (µC) is obtained by integrating the hydrogen desorption region and then dividing it by the sweep rate and 0.21 (µC/cm2) presents the required charge to oxidize a monolayer of hydrogen on the Pt surface. It is clear that the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst has the active area of 99.6 cm2, it is much higher than those of the Pt/C, Pt/C-Pt and Pt/C-CeO2-Pt electrocatalysts (57.0, 70.4 and 80.6 cm2) respectively (as provided in Table S3). Further, the ECSA is quantitatively estimated by normalizing the Pt active area with the total Pt weight presented onto the surface of electrocatalysts (Table S1). The ECSA of the obtained Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt catalyst is approximately determined to be 77.8 m2/gPt, which is 1.7, 1.3 and 1.2 times greater than those of the Pt/C (45.6 m2/gPt), Pt/C-Pt (58.2 m2/gPt) and Pt/C-CeO2-Pt (63.5 m2/gPt), respectively (as shown in Fig. 6b). The higher ECSAs of the Pt/C electrocatalyst coupled with CeO2-based supports can be a result of the good dispersion of the Pt catalyst on its large microporous surface that leads to a large active surface of the Pt catalyst. In addition, the hydroxyl-rich species (OHads) formed on the surface of CeO2-based materials from dissociation of water can be active to remove the hydrogen intermediates (Hads) produced during the HOR, thus improving the HOR performance. In addition, methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) is also tested in N2-saturated solution of 0.5 M H2SO4 + 1 M CH3OH so as to evaluate the electrocatalytic activities of the above-prepared electrocatalysts. As can be seen in the CV results in Fig. 6c, well-defined symmetric anodic peaks are detected at around 0.7 V in the forward sweep and these can correspond to the characteristic oxidation of methanol in acid electrolyte. In the backward sweep, anodic oxidation peaks are observed at around 0.45 V, these are possibly related to the oxidation of the residual carbon intermediates (for example COads) [3]. Furthermore, the onset potentials of electrocatalysts, which relates to break the C-H bonds and the following removal of COads species [56], is obtained as well. The Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt catalyst shows more negative shift of the onset potential (0.26 V vs SCE) as compared to those of the Pt/C (0.36 V vs SCE), Pt/C-Pt (0.35 V vs SCE) and Pt/C-CeO2-Pt (0.29 V vs SCE) catalysts, respectively (Table S3). The significant negative shift of the onset potential of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt can be due to the presence of Au@CeO2 NPs as efficient co-catalyst, which helps remove COads as main poisoning species [57]. Thus, it agrees that the MOR activity on the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt catalyst is much higher among all of the as-prepared catalysts. This result is approved by the forward and backward peak current density (If/Ib) ratios, which can be utilized to demonstrate the CO tolerance of electrocatalysts in MOR performance [58]. Specifically, the higher If/Ib catalyst indicates the better COads tolerance ability. The If, Ib and If/Ib values of the as-prepared electrocatalysts are supplied in Table S3 as well. The If/Ib ratios are found to be 1.16 for Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt, 1.15 for Pt/C-CeO2-Pt, 0.92 for Pt/C-Pt and 0.75 for Pt/C catalyst electrodes. Clearly, the COads tolerance ability of the Pt/C catalyst is greatly improved by the support of CeO2 NPs. In particular, the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt catalyst shows the best COads tolerance. In addition, the mass activity of the MOR performance of electrocatalysts is determined by normalizing forward peak current density with the Pt loading. The mass activity is determined to be 560 mA/mgPt for Pt/C, 826 mA/mgPt for Pt/C-Pt, 944 mA/mgPt for Pt/C-CeO2-Pt and 1267 mA/mgPt for Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt catalysts (Fig. 6d). Certainly, the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt owns the highest mass activity, which is 2.3, 1.5 and 1.3 times higher than those of Pt/C, Pt/C-Pt and Pt/C-CeO2-Pt catalysts, respectively. The MOR stability of electrocatalyst is also an important feature to consider for its practical applications. In this regard, the CVs of all of the as-prepared electrocatalysts were investigated in N2-saturated solution of 0.5 M H2SO4 + 1 M CH3OH electrolyte up to 1000 sequential cycles and the results are shown in Fig. S10. In addition, Fig. 6e shows that the MOR forward peak current density for all of the as-prepared electrocatalysts are steadily decreased due to the poisoning by COads-like species [59] and the agglomeration of the Pt catalyst, which leads to decreasing electrocatalytic activity. The Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt catalyst demonstrates the best MOR stability among the as-prepared electrocatalysts. It decreases the activity by 28% after 1000 cycles, whereas the Pt/C-CeO2-Pt, Pt/C-Pt and Pt/C electrocatalysts respectively lose 42, 63 and 78% activity (Fig. 6f). As can be seen, the electrocatalytic properties of Pt/C is greatly improved with the assistance of CeO2-based materials. The superior MOR activity of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst is further comparable to previous reports of Pt/oxides and Pt/metals catalysts (Tables S4 and S5). Also, the MOR activity of the Pt/C and Pt-Ru/C commercial (their structures are supported in Figs. S11 and S12) is conducted in the same conditions to compare with the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt catalyst, the results are given in Fig. S13a. As can be seen in Fig. 7 a, the MOR mass activity of the Pt-Ru/C electrocatalyst (1320 mA/mgPt) is not much higher than that obtained from the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt (1267 mA/mgPt), while the Pt/C commercial demonstrates poor MOR mass activity (616 mA/mgPt). However, the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst owns good MOR durability compared to Pt-Ru/C and Pt/C commercial one. Namely, after 1000 sequential cycles, the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt only loses 28% activity, whereas the Pt-Ru/C and Pt/C reduce 38 and 70% activity (Fig. 7b and S13b, c), respectively. The microstructure of as-used Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst after the MOR stability test is confirmed by FESEM observation. As can be seen in Fig. S14a, the aggregation of the Pt catalysts can be occurred on the surface of electrocatalyst as an essential result of the long stability test [60,61]. The catalyst layer is further detected by the FESEM-EDS cross-sectional imagery (Fig. S14b). In which, the presence of C, Pt, Au, Ce and O elements are clearly observed as shown in Fig. S14c. The corresponding overlay image is provided in Fig. S14d. Thereby, the microstructure of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst is still maintained, which is clear proof of its highly durable performance. In order to evaluate the CO tolerance of all of the as-prepared electrocatalysts, the CO stripping voltammetry is measured in N2-saturated solution of 0.5 M H2SO4. From the CO stripping voltammetry results of the Pt/C, Pt/C-Pt, Pt/C-CeO2-Pt and Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalysts (Figs. S15(a–d)), the absence of the hydrogen desorption region in the first cycle is that hydrogen adsorption is suppressed due to CO poisoning. In the second cycle, the appearance of the hydrogen desorption region can be clearly seen after the successive oxidation of surface adsorbed CO species [3]. Fig. 8 a compares the CO stripping voltammetry profiles for all of as-prepared electrocatalysts. The onset potential observes at 0.49 (V vs SCE) for CO oxidation on the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst, which is the most negative compared to those of Pt/C (0.51 V vs SCE), Pt/C-Pt (0.54 V vs SCE) and Pt/C-CeO2-Pt (0.53 V vs SCE) electrocatalysts, respectively. Accordingly, the CeO2-based catalysts often show lower onset potentials compared to solely Pt particle [26,62]. This indicates that the obtained electrocatalyst can decrease the adsorption strength of CO species on catalyst in the presence of Au@CeO2 NPs, which provide plenty of hydroxyl species playing a major role to totally transfer CO to CO2 and then leaving CO-free Pt catalyst surfaces. Note that, the CO stripping curve of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrode describes a significant shoulder at lower potentials as compared to others. It can be a result of the multi-catalytic layers structure of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrode, then provides much different sites for CO adsorption during CO stripping measurement. On the other hand, the ECSA of the prepared electrocatalysts are also determined from CO stripping measurement. Thereby, the ECSA is found to be 142.6, 76.5, 58.8 and 50.1 m2/gPt for Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt, Pt/C-CeO2-Pt, Pt/C-Pt and Pt/C electrocatalysts, respectively. The ECSAs obtained from CO stripping are often higher than those obtained from hydrogen region in HOR activity. The reason for this, the adsorption of CO species on surface of Pt will provide larger surface coverages due to the larger kinetic diameter of adsorbed CO molecules as compared to atomic hydrogen [63]. On the other hand, the EIS is also tested in N2-saturated solution of 0.5 M H2SO4 + 1 M CH3OH electrolyte in order to measure the internal resistance of all of the as-prepared electrocatalysts. The EIS spectra are analyzed using Nyquist plots (Fig. 8b), which are fitted with an equivalent circuit, as given in Fig. S16, where, Rs indicates the solution resistance, Rct presents the charge transfer resistance and CPE is a constant phase element. All EIS spectra contain a semicircle portion, with the small diameter of the semicircle (small Rct) demonstrates low charge transfer resistance of the MOR activity. From the given equivalent circuit, the Rct value is calculated to be 86 Ω for Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt, 106 Ω for Pt/C-CeO2-Pt, 127 Ω for Pt/C-Pt and 155 Ω for Pt/C electrocatalysts, respectively. In general, the introduction of CeO2-based materials to Pt/C catalyst could contribute to the decrease of Rct at the interface between working electrocatalyst and electrolyte, in particular, the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt shows the smallest internal resistance among all of the as-prepared electrocatalysts. For this reality, the role of each catalyst layer in the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt structure is clarified as follows. The Pt EPD layer serves as main catalyst as the system exposed to electrolyte. While, the Au@CeO2 layer can act as good supporter for catalyst reactions, even, it is porous substrate for uniform EPD deposition of Pt to improve ECSA of electrode as well. On the other hand, the Pt/C layer in this structure can firstly catalyze for catalysis reactions due to the thickness of Pt EPD and Au@CeO2 supported layers is thin, the electrolyte can be accessible to the Pt catalyst in Pt/C. It is also a buffering layer to reduce the agglomeration of Pt catalyst in EPD layer. And, the Pt/C layer can further act as good conductivity bridge for extracting the generated electrons from the surface electrode to substrate [64]. Therefore, the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt catalyst, with high ECSA, deposited on carbon cloth with the MPL as good conductive substrate could shorten the mass diffusion paths for accelerating electron transport, it leads to excellent electrical contact with the current collectors, as a result, allowing the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst to efficiently take part in electrochemical reactions. The schematic models for explaining the high electrocatalytic performance and long stability for MOR of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst are described in Fig. 8c. In fact, the methanol oxidation on the surface of Pt catalyst consists of two parallel reaction path ways, including a direct and an indirect (CH3OH → COads → CO2 and CH3OH → HCHO, HCOOH → COads → CO2) [65]. Therefore, CO-like species (COads) can be considered as main poisoning intermediate in the MOR activity, resulting in a steady deactivation of the catalyst [66,67]. Basically, the catalytic properties of Pt/C become better when separating Pt catalysts in two layers (Pt/C-Pt case), this can increase the ECSA and thus improving the MOR activity. However, the MOR performance of Pt/C-Pt can be decreased by the COads poisoning effect. This limitation can be partially improved by the support of CeO2 (Pt/C-CeO2-Pt case). Here, the superior advantages of Au@CeO2 core-shell NPs, as an efficient co-catalyst, contributing to the improvement of the electrocatalytic property of Pt/C (Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt case) is proposed as follows. (i) Producing abundant OHads groups. As mentioned previously, the Au/CeO2 composite catalysts have high activity to oxidize the CO species [44,68–72]. As it is confirmed by the XPS analysis, Au@CeO2 catalyst owns high content of the active surface species (as oxygen vacancies and chemisorbed oxygen), as compared to pure CeO2, which could be more activated under an applied potential. Then, H2O molecules are adsorbed to the active surface species [73] and are dissociated to the abundant OHads groups attached to the surface of oxide [25,26,30,38,74] as illustrated in Fig. 8c1. These OHads groups could directly oxidize COads intermediates on the Pt surface, producing CO2 through a bifunctional mechanism. Then, the clean active sites of the Pt catalyst and the original oxygen vacancy of Au@CeO2 NPs are reverted for further methanol electrooxidation. The bifunctional mechanism reactions on the surface of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt system are given as: Au@CeO2 + H2O → Au@CeO2–OHads + H++e, Pt–COads + OHads–Au@CeO2 → Pt + Au@CeO2 + CO2 + H++e; (ii) Reducing charge transfer resistance. Due to the large ECSA, the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt catalyst was loaded onto carbon cloth with the MPL as good conductive substrate, which can lead to reduce the mass diffusion ways for reducing charge transfer resistance, making Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst more advantage to efficiently take part in electrochemical reactions; (iii) Electron modulation effect. Because of f-p hybridization, the 4f electrons in the ground state in CeO2 can transfer to the Pt catalyst, which changes the electron structure [25] and increases the electron density of the d orbitals of Pt atoms. These lead to weaken adsorptive strength of the COads species [75], thus reducing the immediate poisoning effects to enhance the MOR activity; (iv) Enhancing dispersity of the Pt catalyst to increase the triple phase interfaces. Being a highly porous surface, Au@CeO2 NPs can support more surface area for the good dispersion of the Pt catalyst, increasing the triple phase interfaces between Au@CeO2, Pt and electrolyte from the synergistic effect. This leads to the enrichment of OHads groups for the removal of the adsorbed COads poisoning species on the Pt catalyst surface [2,76]. Furthermore, the large surface area and Lewis basicity surface of Au@CeO2 cause the strong anchoring of the Pt catalyst to its surface, which can effectively prevent Ostwald ripening and agglomeration of Pt during MOR activity; (v) Promoting MOR activity due to the existence of Ce3+ ions. Given the coexistence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ in CeO2, this redox can promote the MOR activity when increasing the concentration of Ce3+ ions as well [77]: Ce2O3 + 2H2O → 2CeO2 + 2H+ + 2e, Pt–COads + 2CeO2 + 2H++2e → Ce2O3 + Pt + CO2 + H2O; (vi) Providing more core - shell active interfaces. Au@CeO2 core-shell structures themselves could be active in directly oxidizing the methanol molecules [78]. Particularly due to the porosity of the shell and the methanol molecules being easily accessible to the core-shell effective interfaces (as illustrated Fig. 8c2), there are heterogeneous catalytic sites to wholly oxidize the methanol reactant; and (vii) Preventing the corrosion of carbon supports. Last but not least, as a stable catalyst, the Au@CeO2 core-shell layer can strongly stabilize the sensitive surface of carbon supports from direct exposure to the corrosive environment, then contributes greatly to good durability of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst as well. 4 Conclusion In this work, in order to improve the electrochemical properties of the standard Pt/C catalyst in the MOR activity, a facile and efficient structural electrode is proposed, which consists of the Pt/C, Au@CeO2 and Pt catalysts supported on carbon cloth. In the presence of Au@CeO2 core-shell structures, the main obstacle of the Pt/C catalyst in MOR, which is the COads poisoning effect, could be easily solved. Therefore, the obtained Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst showed high activity for MOR and long stability after 1000 sequential cycles, as compared to the Pt/C catalyst. The improved removal activities of COads intermediates of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst could chiefly be a result of the main effects of Au@CeO2 core-shell structured nanoparticle, such as producing abundant OHads radicals, improving charge transfer resistance of Pt/C electrocatalyst and enhancing the Pt catalytic utilization efficiency. Accordingly, our finding suggests that metal@oxide core-shell structures are effective for improving the electrocatalytic properties of Pt/C in DMFCs applications. coredata.dc:description: Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) are emerging as clean and renewable energy sources for global-scale sustainable energy solutions. However, several limitations of the current standard catalyst (platinum supported carbon black: Pt/C) prevent their commercialization. As an effective co-catalyst, Au@CeO2 core-shell structures are greatly advantageous for getting over the remaining hurdles of Pt/C in DMFCs. Herein, we report an efficient approach for the fabrication of electrocatalyst for DMFCs consisting of three components (Pt/C, Au@CeO2 and Pt catalysts) loaded on carbon cloth using spray and electrophoresis deposition methods. The obtained Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst proved to have high electrochemical surface area (ECSA-77.8 m2/gPt) and high methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) activity (1267 mA/mgPt), which were 1.7 and 2.3 times greater than those of Pt/C only (45.6 m2/gPt and 560 mA/mgPt). In addition, the presence of Au@CeO2 nanoparticles can further enhance the stability of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst toward the MOR activity. The improved MOR performance of the Pt/C-Au@CeO2-Pt electrocatalyst could be mainly attributed to the production of abundant OHads promoters, reduction of charge transfer resistance and enhancement of Pt catalytic efficient utilization. It helps to wholly oxidize COads intermediate as dominant poisoning species on Pt catalyst, which are often generated during the MOR operation in acidic condition.
coredata.dc:title: Au@CeO2 nanoparticles supported Pt/C electrocatalyst to improve the removal of CO in methanol oxidation reaction
